Authors:
Leticia Maria Kumar, Matthew E Smith, Eduardo Nouhra,
Takamichi Orihara, Pablo Sandoval, Donald H. Pfister, David J
McLaughlin, Rosanne Healy
Title:
A molecular and morphological re-examination of the generic
limits of truffles in the Tarzetta-Geopyxis lineage Â– Densocarpa,
Hydnocystis, and Paurocotylis
Keywords:
Hypogeous fungi, truffle evolution, Gondwanan
distribution
Abstract:
Phylogenetic analyses of the ITS and 28S nuclear ribosomal
DNA from recently collected members of the /tarzetta-geopyxis lineage
from North America and South America prompted a reinvestigation of
species and generic limits in the truffle genera Hydnocystis,
Paurocotylis, and Stephensia. Our analyses support emendations of
Hydnocystis and Paurocotylis and the resurrection of the genus
Densocarpa. Because the type species of Stephensia, S. bombycina, is
phylogenetically nested within Hydnocystis, Stephensia is treated as a
synonym of Hydnocystis and we transfer S. bombycina to Hydnocystis.
Hydnocystis singeri is phylogenetically nested within Paurocotylis so we
transfer Hydnocystis singeri to Paurocotylis. Stephensia bynumii is
phylogenetically supported as a species of Paurocotylis, so we combine
it as P. bynumii. This is the first detection of the genus Paurocotylis
in the Americas. To accommodate other Stephensia species, we use the
genus Densocarpa for a North American species, D. shanorii, and a
European species, D. crocea. We describe two new species, Hydnocystis
transitoria from North America and Paurocotylis patagonica from South
America. We review anamorphic forms and evaluate the morphological
characters used to delimit truffle genera within the /tarzetta-geopyxis
lineage in light of new phylogenetic evidence. Our work highlights the
unexplored diversity, morphological plasticity, and remaining taxonomic
problems in the /tarzetta-geopyxis lineage.
